author: {'steamid': '76561198080601479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1457452827}
review:
The 4.4 hrs on record was the time that it took me to play through this game once, entirely. I wanted to review this from Act 1, but thought it would be better to save it until Act 3 was released. Now that all the acts have been released and played I figured now was the perfect time.

I personally really enjoyed this game. It's more or less a simplified point-and-click game where all you need to do is really press 1 of 3 buttons to make decisions in game. The characters of this game are also wonderfully written and funny. On top of this, the whole game takes place on a theatre stage with you as an audience member who is also the director (somehow) who decides many of the lines in the game. 

I would personally say that Act 1 starts off a little slowly (but considering the game is set on stage like a play, this is expected) in that not much really begins to happen until the very end of Act 1. In my opinion from the second half of Act 2 to Act 3 is where everything ramps up dramatically. To me, the entirety of Act 3 was the best part of this game.

I'd recommend this game to you if you're looking for an episodic style game where you don't need to be paying attention 100% of the time as there are (thankfully) no quick time events. 

My only complaint would MAYBE be the current price of it. It was ¬£10.99 (UK, full price) at the original date of posting this review, and for something that took 4.4hrs to complete. But then again, you get SO MUCH of that value in Act 3 alone. A definite recommendation from me!

I like the aeshetic of this game a lot. It's artsy and weird in a good way. 
The gameplay is very simple and streamlined - you just make dialog choices and choose one of 3 spins on the reports you publish. The game even alerts you to when your choices "matter" and then later when the effects of those choices materialize, exposing the inner workings of the game model rather than trying to hide it from you. The game cuts out all the walking around and re-checking the people you might have already talked to for new clues, just takes you straight from one dialog choice to the next. So it feels like you're always driving forward at a fast pace (even though there are no actual time constraints or anything)
But there are tons of little details everywhere that really flesh out the world. Random signs people are holding, other set dressing, the way that the characters move as they are transported from one set to the next. The pseudo-theater metaphor really works well. It draws parallels between the limitations of the two genres (see, artsy). There are funny moments that have absolutely nothing to do with the story.
Plus, you get to play as a girl who says weird non-sequitur stuff *and* a guy with a bloodhound. and also some third guy who's OK.

review:
Update #2:
I can't believe I'm revising my review once again but after finishing Act 1 (life has gotten in the way of playing - always a drag), my enthusiasm has only increased.  As with a good film, I'm swept up in the story and the mechanics of its telling. I really wanted to sit through the credits that cleverly display when you choose a "bathroom break" at the end of the Act.  I'm definitely looking forward to Acts 2 and 3 but as importantly, the next project this team tackles.  I hope they can remain viable.  I've been a gamer for over 50 years and it's rare to see a game that so expertly captures my other passions: movies and theater.  I've enjoyed such cinematic games as Life is Strange but Knee Deep nails the emotional experience evoked by the best of the arts.  It is a gaming masterpiece.

Update:
Please note the dev's comments that I am wrong regarding length of Act 1.  That would indicate the length, with all three acts, is good.  Regardless, I bought it even though I thought it might be short.

Orginal review:
For those of us who love cinematic games, this is a terrific addition.  It deftly provides the cinematics in a theatrical manner that is graphically dynamic and highly unusual.  The characters are a bit stiff and rough in comparison but that doesn't detract from the visceral pleasure of advancing an interesting story line.  With sublime lighting and evocative music, Knee Deep has flair to spare.  And for those who may be put off by earlier reviews citing lack of vocalization, know that the devs have listened and supplied voiceovers to great effect.  I've also noticed they have responded to most, if not all, of the reviews here which generally signals devs who really care.  If you're on the fence, just play the demo.  That's what hooked me.  Even though the game may be short (the demo is supposed to be all of Act 1 and I finished it in less than two hours), I decided these devs deserve support.  There are some reviews that compare this to Telltale games but I think in many ways, Telltale and other "choice-oriented" adventure game companies could learn from these folks.

Dies geht sogar soweit, dass man die Hintergrundgeschichte und Vergangenheit der Spieler-Charaktere durch seine Antworten in Diaglogen ver√§ndern kann. Man wird beispielsweise gefragt was damals in der Schule vorgefallen ist und die Antwort bestimmt was tats√§chlich passiert ist.

Personen die interactive-movie Spiele m√∂gen (hier ist es nach dem Setup eher ein interaktives Theaterst√ºck).

review:
[i]DISCLAIMER: This is a review of the first episode. No score will be given. A full review of the entire season will follow once all three episodes have been released.[/i]

It‚Äôs a good thing that I‚Äôm playing this game on a hot summer evening. It‚Äôs also interesting that I live just a few miles away from one of the largest swampland areas in Europe and the humidity, as always, is unbearable. It‚Äôs just curious that there are no mosquitoes tonight. All in all, a perfect situation to immerse myself into Knee Deep, a self-proclaimed swamp noir in three acts. And I am immersed in a matter of seconds. The first thing that strikes me is the music, a brilliantly moody mixture of American folk and blues. I start the game up and I am immediately seated in a theater. I silence my mobile phone out of respect for the actors. As the curtain rises on the stage, I find myself in a backwater Florida town of Cypress Knee. It‚Äôs a grim start as a washed-up actor has hanged himself from a tower next to a local inn.

It is at that time that I am called up to control the story. Even though a wider narrative is in place, the player is able to move the story along through the actions of three distinct characters. Romana Teague, a 20-year-old blogger kicks things off as she decided to report on the apparent suicide. Then there‚Äôs Jack Bellet, a local reporter whose career and marriage is falling apart. Lastly, private investigator K.C. Gaddis, hired by the film studio to look into Tag Kern‚Äôs suicide, arrives on the scene as well. Not all is as it seems in Cypress Knee and each character will stumble onto different pieces of information as they survey the surroundings and talk to the locals. Certain critical choices will affect relationships with other characters. Also, as you uncover certain details, you can choose which story to run and what spin to put on it. Whether you choose to keep things grounded, put an edgy spin on a story, or go all out sensationalist, it will have an effect on the narrative and other characters. What I found most compelling was the ability to choose the playable characters‚Äô past and motivations and that is something I hope to see more of in upcoming episodes.

The overall story is certainly intriguing with all manner of seedy and eccentric characters. However, the writing is a bit of a hit-and-miss. Romana in particular comes off as rather obnoxious too often in an attempt to be snarky and that‚Äôs definitely not a trait you want the lead character to have. Some situations are realized to great effect while others fall flat. The gameplay revolves around choosing responses when interacting with characters and choosing which story to write and what spin to put on it. There are only two puzzles in the game and they‚Äôre an extremely basic affair of putting several puzzle pieces together. It is clear that the gameplay in Knee Deep takes a backseat to storytelling and atmosphere. And the atmosphere is truly palpable.

Aside from the already mentioned brilliant soundtrack, certain graphical effects are pulled off masterfully as well. While the graphics are technically rather modest, the slick utilization of a theater stage makes up for it. The game takes place during a single evening and the stage is mostly very dark with a few lights coming on to highlight points of interest. As the lead characters enter buildings, the outer walls and ceilings rise up to reveal the interior. Also, as you go from one location to another, the entire stage rotates and changes the backdrop. It‚Äôs truly an inspired series of effects that completely nail the vibe of both a dark stage and a small Florida swamp town.

The first act will take you about 2 hours to finish, so it‚Äôs a bit short even for an episodic game. I played through it a second time to see how different choices affect the story and to get some achievements. The remaining two acts will follow at an undetermined date. The end of Act 1 brings closure to this particular part of the story, but there are still things left to uncover.

[b]THE VERDICT[/b]

Knee Deep Act 1: Wonderland is a solid start with an intriguing story, lots of choices and interesting characters. A bit too light on gameplay, it does manage to make up for it mostly due to its fantastic presentation which masterfully uses graphical effects and music to provide a strong sense of place.

Knee Deep is an episodic murder mystery game following three protagonists who come together to solve the murders happening in their hometown of Cypress Knee. The setting is set on a stage and it's really surprising the first time when you see the buildings and environment being built right in front of your very own eyes. You as the player have some control over the three main characters of the play. I say some because I felt as though some of the selections that were given felt forced on me. 

Anyways, there are choices you can make (in a form of news reports that you can send to your editor/boss), that will determine how other non-playable actors will react to you.  Now, since there‚Äôs only one act, I am not sure how much of an impact my decisions will have on future acts so that is to be determined. I will update as more acts are added.

The characters are quirky, albeit strange at times but they all have unique personalities that set them apart from each other. I mean it‚Äôs not every day someone asks you to feed a raw chicken wearing a diaper to an alligator. (However, if this is an everyday occurrence to you, please call me.) Some of the dialogues are funny and the story is engaging. I believe it took me about 3.5 hours to complete the first act so it‚Äôs not too long. 

I would recommend this game, especially since the price dropped to $9.99. The developers are pretty responsive to their players. 

I‚Äôm not much for scoring but I suppose I would rate the first act a 7/10.

review:
I had a great time with Knee Deep. It's very much in the spirit of Telltale's iconic Walking Dead and Wolf Among Us games, using well-written (and frequently hilarious) dialogue-branch gameplay to further the narrative.

The big thing that struck me was Knee Deep's staging and production design. It's a modestly sized project, but you can tell a lot of thought went into how each scene transitions from one to the next through clever lighting and inspired set design. Buildings spiral, transform, and rotate to take you to each new location, creating a gorgeously fun ballet out of limited art assets.

If I have any gripes at all, it's that I found the swelling cast of characters tough to tell apart after a while. Since many of the scenes are told through static, stage-play inspired shots, it was tough to get a good look at anyone's face up close. I would have loved to have seen an occasional close-up during heated moments to build some intimacy and tension.

Very much looking forward to Act II!

Having just finished Act 1, I can say that Knee Deep was a really fun ride. The basics are that you investigate a little racist roadside attraction that has become a hotbed of nationwide attention after an actor seemingly commits suicide there. There are three main characters you control in different "scenes" of the play and you write an update for your character's boss (or audience) using facts you gather. 

+ The writing is great. I laughed out loud several times choosing the "interesting" dialogue choices
+ The story and characters are engaging. The ending had a lot happen at once which is overwhelming but I am invested in Act 2 and want to see how they develop it. Going to go through again to see how much the choices affect outcomes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194008557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1453514890}
review:
ACT 1 REVIEW:  (Also Act 2 Review below)

Knee Deep is an absorbing world which introduces you to three characters you will play and a dark, steamy florida night, complete with cricket sounds and twangy soundtrack.  I emerged, several hours later, pondering the clues I had uncovered and wondering what will happen next? An exciting, well-staged cliffhanger at the end of this episode got my pulse racing as events rapidly escalated to an unexpected conclusion.  
I love this theatrical premise, with gorgeous sets and lighting, and I find the characters fun to play. There are choices to make which influence how other characters will respond to you (whether they will give you much information, for example), but you really cannot fail at this game, which encourages you to take risks and experiment. The game conveniently stores discovered information and clues for you in an easily accessible journal which you can refer to at any time. I found this particularly helpful as there is a lot going on in this first episode.
Cannot wait for the next installment and glad to hear it will be out in just a few months.  Meanwhile, I will be playing this again and making different choices, just to see what happens! A game which rewards experimentation and which is, in a word, FUN.

ACT 2 REVIEW:

Knee Deep's Wonderland offers new scenes but continues its strangely addicting combination of murder mystery with witty (often snarky) repartee. I love the option of choosing edgy reporting or weird responses. Why not? It's a game, not real life. I can take risks.
Still in Cypress Knee, that strangely familiar Florida town, but now there is a weirdly creepy fair complete with a  set of rhyming villagers reminiscent of an off-kilter broadway musical. The body count continues to grow as the clues accumulate...
The occasional short interlude of "match the patterm" challenge allows a chance to engage a different part of your brain.  This act is well paced and all in all, an excellent use of the 90 minutes or so it takes to play it. Great fun all around, and I look forward to the final act.

review:
With one fairly quick, but thoroughly enjoyable run through of Act I, I feel like Knee Deep is a game I never knew I wanted to play.

I may be subject to some genre bias, narrative adventure is something I genuinely enjoy, but I feel Knee Deep has performed admirably in this regard. The characters are engaging, if not always likeable, the story is superbly written and the mystery itself enough to make me want to keep digging.

When it comes to negative points. If you're after action, or a rich puzzle-filled experience, as some other adventure games showcase, Knee Deep may not be for you. As I'm sure it says in the description somewhere, and probably another review, the game is about choice, dialogue, and character (As I see). The dialogue also falls into a similar problem I found in L.A. Noire (Admittedly a very different game) where the dialogue choices you make may not always be quite clear on the tone you're about to throw at a witness/friend/boss. But all in all, very minor problems.

The choice of graphical style is quirky, but fits seamlessly into the tone of the story as it's written. Witty dialogue, wacky backdrops, and a story and characters that could really have come from a Florida backwater. With only one playthrough of one act under my belt, I'm sure that Knee Deep is money well spent.

review:
Knee Deep is a bizarre game from its artstyle, narrative, and themes, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. 
Knee Deep tells the tale of three different characters all investigating an apparent suicide. The story takes place in the back waters of swampland Florida. There are all sorts of strange characters all with possibly shady pasts and even shadier motives. From Remy who keeps telling you useless facts, to the strange religion that seemingly is connected to everybody. These characters and interactions is what makes Knee Deep rich. The basic mechanics of the game are simple, this is a visual novel with an interesting aesthetic. You go through the game talking to many characters trying to find out what really is going on. What makes Knee Deep unique is that you form the narrative in many ways, from inner monologue to the back story of certain characters. Things can play out many different ways and it adds a lot of replay value. Occasionally I found the animations and the way conversations ended rather odd. This could be due to Knee Deep being a stageplay that you are watching. As far from a technical standpoint everything works well but increasing the shadow quality of the game caused massive frame drops. This became noticeable and I had to lower the quality to get a smooth game. In all this isn't your usual style of Visual novel, It tries to be different for better or worse. If you come into this expecting a traditional visual novel or something more akin to Telltales games, you may be disappointed. On the other hand if you approach this, curious about weird characters and an unusual murder mystery you might enjoy Knee Deep. It also helps that there is two more acts coming that are completely free with the purchase of the game.

This is a game for those who love a good story: Complex and believable characters struggle with seemingly insurmountable odds. In classic mystery fashion, our three main investigators start with a seemingly simple suicide, only to unearth a snakes‚Äô den of unsavory characters and forces. Like any good old ingrown community, everyone has an intertwined, violent and/or illegal backstory. 

The overall plot backbone is constant, but your conversation and reporting choices open unique subplots and relationship angles: Will he make his cocaine pickup? Will one main character expose another‚Äôs dark past? Who lives and who dies? I‚Äôve enjoyed playing through the game several times, trying to uncover new story angles and clues. One thing is for certain, the Act 1 conclusion was completely unexpected and has me dying (no pun) to get my hands on Acts 2 & 3.

This is NOT a game for world explorers or physical clue gumshoes. The designers hold to the stage metaphor and focus your attention on one scene at a time. The 3D world is stage-minimalistic. The sets and lighting nicely capture the nightmarish quality of a backwater town on a hot, muggy night. The 3D characters and their animations are simple but effective. The music was a pleasant surprise for me ‚Äî haunting and ear-worm worthy. 

I enjoy a game with great replay value, and this one lets me explore the consequences of risky convesational styles. I catch glimpses here in Act 1; ultimately, it'll be interesting to see how Acts 2 & 3 bear out the fruits of my game play.
